information:
Post Malone has received five nominations for the 60th Academy of Country Music (ACM) Awards, scheduled for May 8, 2025. His nominations include Album of the Year for "F-1 Trillion," and three nominations for his collaboration with Morgan Wallen, "I Had Some Help." He is not nominated for the top category, Entertainer of the Year. Key competitors include first-time nominee Ella Langley, who leads with eight nominations. Other heavily nominated artists are Morgan Wallen and Lainey Wilson with seven nominations each, and Chris Stapleton with six nominations.

The reception for cross-genre artists at country music award shows has been mixed historically. Favorable precedents include Beyoncé winning a CMA Award for a collaboration with The Chicks, and Justin Timberlake winning a CMA with Chris Stapleton. Lil Nas X also won CMA Awards for "Old Town Road." However, many artists crossing over face resistance from traditional voters, and the Album of the Year award typically goes to established country artists. Post Malone himself has a history of receiving numerous Grammy nominations without winning; at the 2025 Grammy Awards, he was nominated for eight awards and lost all of them, bringing his career total to 18 nominations without a win.

Post Malone has recently made high-profile moves into the country music scene. His country album, "F-1 Trillion," has had strong commercial performance. He has engaged in collaborations with established country stars such as Morgan Wallen, Luke Combs, Blake Shelton, and Jelly Roll. His recent performance at the Coachella festival featured a country-focused set and guest appearances from Jelly Roll and Ed Sheeran. However, this performance received a mixed reception from viewers and critics.

forecast.status_quo_outcome: No — most nominees in competitive fields typically leave without a win, and cross-genre entrants often face headwinds with country voters
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: I Had Some Help gets edged out by Zach Bryan/Kacey Musgraves, Lainey Wilson, Chris Stapleton, or another core-country favorite for Single/Song; Music Event goes to a different collaboration; Album of the Year goes to an established country act. Post leaves 0-for-4 (or 0-for-5) despite multiple nominations.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: I Had Some Help wins Music Event of the Year or Single of the Year; or it wins Song of the Year and Post receives credit as a songwriter; or a visual/media category (if nominated) breaks his way. Any one win suffices.
forecast.rationale: Timing: We’re ~2 weeks out, so there’s little time for major new information beyond industry buzz or pre-announced winners. Nominations: Background says 4 nominations; the assistant report says 5 (Album of the Year for F-1 Trillion and three categories for I Had Some Help with Morgan Wallen, plus possibly a visual/media nod). Regardless of whether it’s 4 or 5, he has multiple live paths to a win. Category dynamics: Album of the Year is a long shot versus entrenched country stalwarts. The better paths are collaborative/single categories. I Had Some Help was one of the year’s biggest songs by consumption and radio, and ACM voters often reward commercial smashes—particularly in Single and Music Event. Collaboration with Morgan Wallen likely boosts acceptability among voters compared to a pure pop crossover. Countervailing factors: Cross-genre entrants can face resistance; ACMs sometimes consolidate around core-country darlings (Lainey Wilson, Chris Stapleton, Zach Bryan/Kacey Musgraves). It’s plausible the field splits such that Post/Morgan get shut out if voters prioritize perceived ‘core’ country or spread wins across rivals. Grammys shutouts for Post aren’t directly predictive for ACMs, but they illustrate that high nomination counts don’t guarantee wins. Why not higher? Strong competition in each category and the possibility that voters intentionally diversify winners. Why not lower? Multiple independent-ish paths (Music Event, Single, possibly Song credit, and maybe Visual Media) give him several bites at the apple; he doesn’t need to clear Album of the Year to resolve Yes. What would move me up: Confirmation of five (not four) live nominations including Music Event and Single; strong industry chatter tipping I Had Some Help as a frontrunner; odds/pundit consensus coalescing around the collab in at least one category. What would move me down: Final nominee slate confirming fewer live paths (e.g., no Music Event or Songwriter credit), or credible reporting that key categories are leaning to Zach Bryan/Kacey Musgraves, Lainey Wilson, or Stapleton.

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will Post Malone win an award at the 60th Academy of Country Music Awards?

Question background:
The awards are scheduled to be held on May 8, 2025. Malone has 4 nominations.


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question resolves as **Yes** if Post Malone wins an award at the [60th Academy of Country Music Awards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/60th_Academy_of_Country_Music_Awards).




Your research assistant's report says:
Post Malone has received five nominations for the 60th Academy of Country Music (ACM) Awards, scheduled for May 8, 2025. His nominations include Album of the Year for "F-1 Trillion," and three nominations for his collaboration with Morgan Wallen, "I Had Some Help." He is not nominated for the top category, Entertainer of the Year. Key competitors include first-time nominee Ella Langley, who leads with eight nominations. Other heavily nominated artists are Morgan Wallen and Lainey Wilson with seven nominations each, and Chris Stapleton with six nominations.

The reception for cross-genre artists at country music award shows has been mixed historically. Favorable precedents include Beyoncé winning a CMA Award for a collaboration with The Chicks, and Justin Timberlake winning a CMA with Chris Stapleton. Lil Nas X also won CMA Awards for "Old Town Road." However, many artists crossing over face resistance from traditional voters, and the Album of the Year award typically goes to established country artists. Post Malone himself has a history of receiving numerous Grammy nominations without winning; at the 2025 Grammy Awards, he was nominated for eight awards and lost all of them, bringing his career total to 18 nominations without a win.

Post Malone has recently made high-profile moves into the country music scene. His country album, "F-1 Trillion," has had strong commercial performance. He has engaged in collaborations with established country stars such as Morgan Wallen, Luke Combs, Blake Shelton, and Jelly Roll. His recent performance at the Coachella festival featured a country-focused set and guest appearances from Jelly Roll and Ed Sheeran. However, this performance received a mixed reception from viewers and critics.

Today is 2025-04-22.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.

# OUTPUT SCHEMA
{
    "time_left_until_outcome_known": "string",
    "status_quo_outcome": "string",
    "no_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "yes_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "rationale": "string",
    "probability": "number" (0-100)
}
